history.content:
I took EE16B with 54 and was successful. Half of the course is basically just a continuation of circuits from EE16A and linear algebra won't help you very much there (although knowing how to solve differential equations from 54 is somewhat useful). Without self-studying circuits before the semester starts you will be somewhat lost in labs and homeworks and the first midterm will be very hard to do well on (assuming that circuits is taught first, as it was in Spring 2018). The second half of the course is about systems, controls, and signals, which depend somewhat on linear algebra. I felt that this part of the course didn't really rely too much (if at all) on EE16A knowledge besides linear algebra. EE16B is, in my opinion, a hard and time-consuming course in and of itself, but it won't be any harder for you than for someone who took EE16A if you go through the circuits module from EE16A. I would definitely recommend you go through that material.

---

Agree with above responder. I was in the same boat, and did well with a few weeks of prep over the summer. If you do the discussions from last semester on circuits and opamps you'll probably be fine. The first third of the class and the labs will still probably be the most difficult depending on how much prior experience you have from high school physics and generally tinkering with circuits.

If you are concerned about declaring then be prepared to sacrifice your grade in 16B or drop it entirely, as the labs are notoriously time-consuming (this is often the case irrespective of skill level or experience).

children.subject:
There are many reasons why you should take ee classes, one of the most important, the fact that CS is not a self-contained major. There is a lot of ee and math involved in it. At many times, ee, math, and cs will overlap in many dimensions. Math 54 is deprecated by a reason, one of which is the fact that the course is too broad for cs and does not go directly into applications (see Sahai's psets for ee16a or Maharbiz's for ee16b to have an idea of whast I am talking about). EE16AB at the least, is a very interesting combo of courses that allows you to understand general ideas that are key for computer science majors.

The series explores ideas like system design (ee16ab), page rank (ee16a), locationing/trilateration/ambiguity (ee16a), omp + Gram-Schmidt (ee16a), least squares (ee16a), system linearization + controllability + stability + observability (ee16b), SVD + PCA (ee16b) and signals (ee16b). All of these topics should be familiar to you no matter what you do in Computer Science. Systems (especially design) will come up in 168, 152 and 162. Least squares, SVD, and PCA will come up in 189 and 127. Page Rank will come up in 126. If you plan on working in NLP or anything related to voice recognition or the like, you will at least need to feel comfortable on ee16b material of signals to then delve into the topics of 120 and 123.

Berkeley takes it too chill on ee requirements compared to any public university in any other country in the world. In my country a lot more ee is expected from cs majors and the ee that is taught is way more physical than ee16ab (which, to be completely honest, BARELY touches the mechanical and electrical side of things and mostly reduces to math). Instead of complaining about the requirements try to understand why they are there. EE 16AB have been made the new linear algebra / ee-ish requirements for a reason. The things that are taught in those courses often come up not only in upper div classes but also in real-life applications. EE 16AB is a very low-bar lower bound for the understanding that you should have about these things. You should be aiming for at least both and possibly even one more course in ee just because you are in Berkeley and have basically one of the best eecs departments as a resource

P.S.: yes, I am L&S CS and no, I did not do awesome in ee16ab, but I do feel that L&S CS should have more ee

I am not interested at all in EE, so I also took Math 54 instead, and it made more sense for a double with math. I am just going to take EE 16B my second semester senior year and get a D- but be fine with that and graduate. I don't understand why CS majors HAVE TO take ee courses.

history.content:
I just want to hear some advice (and especially experience from those who have done this before).

But I have been contemplating taking EE16B with only Math 54 experience (strong linear background), no circuits experience. How difficult would that be? I've been thinking about doing this because it would allow me more room to take the classes I actually want to take later on in the future. However, my worry is that I still need to declare CS and I'd have to take this class with CS61B. Any tips or advice?
history.subject: Taking EE16B with only Math 54
